openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Austria is classified as a highly developed social market economy, ranking among the fourteen wealthiest countries globally in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) per capita.

• Until the 1980s, many of Austria's largest industrial firms were nationalized; however, recent years have seen a process of privatization that has reduced state holdings to levels comparable with other European economies.
• Austria maintains a highly efficient and robust social security system, with social expenditure accounting for approximately 29.4% of GDP among OECD nations.
• Labor movements in Austria are notably strong and exert significant influence over labor politics, reflecting the country's active labor sector.
• International tourism is the second most important sector in Austria's economy after highly developed industry, playing a crucial role in economic activity.
• Austria's average GDP growth rate from 1992 to 2017 ranked 13th among OECD countries, with a notable population growth rate of 1.37% above the national average, contributing to economic expansion.
• Historically, Germany has been Austria's primary trading partner, which has made Austria's economy susceptible to rapid fluctuations in the German economy.

• Since Austria's accession to the European Union, the country has strengthened economic ties with other EU member states, reducing its dependence on Germany and attracting increased foreign investment.
• EU membership has facilitated access to the European Single Market and proximity to emerging economies within the EU, fostering economic growth.
• Austria's GDP growth rate accelerated in recent years, reaching 3.3% in 2006.
• In 2024, Austria's nominal GDP per capita is estimated at $58,669, ranking 13th globally.
• Vienna is ranked as the fifth richest NUTS-2 region within Europe, with a GDP per capita of €38,632, trailing behind Inner London, Luxembourg, the Brussels-Capital Region, and Hamburg.
• Between 2002 and 2006, Austria experienced steady economic growth, fluctuating between 1% and 3.3%.
• In 2013, Austria's GDP growth rate was 0%, indicating stagnation, but growth picked up thereafter, reaching 1.5% in 2016.

• The provided section on the "Economy of Austria" under the "History" chapter is incomplete and lacks substantive content, primarily consisting of a notice that the section requires additional citations for verification.

• The section contains a standard Wikipedia disclaimer emphasizing that unsourced material may be challenged and removed, highlighting the importance of proper citation for academic and encyclopedic integrity.

• No specific historical data, dates, figures, organizations, individuals, or economic concepts are included within the provided excerpt, suggesting that the actual content related to Austria's economic history is missing or has yet to be added.

• The placeholder text indicates an ongoing editorial process aimed at improving the article's reliability through citation enhancement, rather than presenting any substantive historical economic information.
• The First Austrian Republic was established following the dissolution of Austria-Hungary, inheriting an economy severely damaged by World War I.
• Key economic issues inherited included the abolition of the gold standard in 1914, which disrupted monetary stability.
• The central bank provided credit to the state, resulting in an increased money supply that contributed to inflationary pressures.
• Austria faced a significant balance-of-payments deficit due to the necessity of importing food and fuel, which led to the devaluation of the krone, the Austrian currency at the time.
• The government employed deficit spending to finance food subsidies, causing a twelvefold increase in banknotes in circulation, thereby fueling inflation.
• Several international relief schemes attempted to stabilize the Austrian economy but failed to attract sufficient support.
• A report by Sir William Goode emphasized that Austria's economic collapse was imminent without prompt foreign intervention.
• The Austrian economic crisis persisted into its second year, with inflation reaching a rate of 99%.
• In August 1922, the League of Nations was officially appointed to organize an Austrian reconstruction plan amidst an inflation rate of 2,877%.

• The League’s scheme was based on the premise that Austria’s economic difficulties stemmed from an inability to pay for necessities and obtain credit, making financial revival essential for Austrian survival.

• The reconstruction plan focused exclusively on financial measures, involving Austria receiving loans raised from international money markets and the Austrian public, secured on customs and tobacco taxes.
• As part of the agreement, Austria would effectively lose sovereignty over its economy, agreeing to:
• These measures took effect in 1923, producing impressive short-term results; during the announcement of reconstruction in August 1922, public confidence increased significantly.

• The stabilization of the currency was achieved as foreign currency holdings were converted back into the krone, stabilizing the currency and enabling the Austrian Foreign Exchange Agency to intervene and fix the krone to the dollar, ending the previous currency gyrations.
• Capital inflows resumed, and domestic prices stabilized, marking the end of hyperinflation in Austria.
• However, the initial positive effects were short-lived; economic growth averaged only 0.35% per annum until 1929.
• During this period, unemployment increased five-fold, bankruptcies surged 41-fold, and the trade deficit doubled.
• Austria was annexed by Nazi Germany in 1938, an event commonly referred to as the Anschluss.
• The annexation resulted in Austria losing control over its own economic policy from 1938 until 1945.
• During this period, Austria's economic policies were governed by Nazi Germany's central authorities rather than its own government.
• The annexation marked a significant political and economic integration of Austria into the German Reich, impacting its economic sovereignty.
• The period of annexation lasted until the end of World War II, culminating in the re-establishment of Austria as an independent state with the formation of the Second Republic in 1945.
• Since the end of World War II, Austria has experienced sustained economic growth.
• During the 1950s, a period of vigorous rebuilding, Austria's economy grew at an average annual rate of more than 5% in real terms.
• Throughout most of the 1960s, Austria's real GDP growth averaged approximately 4.5% annually.
• In the mid-1990s, Austria's economy experienced moderate growth: 1.7% in 1995, 2% in 1996, and 1.2% in 1997.
• Following this period, Austria's economy rebounded with real GDP growth of 2.9% in 1998 and 2.2% in 1999.
• Austria joined the European Union (EU) on 1 January 1995, marking a significant integration milestone.
• EU membership provided Austria with economic benefits, including increased foreign investment attracted by access to the single European market.
• The country faced certain economic challenges following EU accession, but overall progress was made in enhancing international competitiveness.
• Austria's economy is highly integrated with other EU member states, especially with Germany, as part of the European Union's economic and monetary union (EMU).
• On 1 January 1999, Austria adopted the Euro as its new currency for accounting purposes.
• In January 2002, Euro banknotes and coins were introduced, replacing the Austrian schilling entirely.
• Austria adopted the euro as its official currency in 1999, joining 18 other EU member states to form the Eurozone.
• Although the euro was introduced in 1999, all Austrian euro coins issued from 2002 bear the year 2002, whereas in other Eurozone countries, the minting year is typically inscribed on the coins.
• The Austrian euro coins feature eight different designs, with each design corresponding to a specific face value.
• In 2007, Austria changed the common side of its euro coins to align with the new Eurozone map design used by other member states.
• Prior to adopting the euro, Austria used the Austrian schilling as its currency, which was first established in December 1924.
• The schilling was abolished in 1938 following the Anschluss but was reintroduced in November 1945 after World War II ended.
• Austria has one of the most extensive collections of collector's coins within the Eurozone, with face values ranging from 10 to 100 euros.
• In 2004, Austria minted an exceptionally rare coin with a face value of 100,000 euros.
• These collector's coins are a legacy of Austria's historical practice of minting silver and gold coins, reflecting its numismatic heritage.

• Unlike standard euro coins, Austrian collector's coins are not legal tender throughout the Eurozone; for example, a €5 Austrian commemorative coin cannot be used as legal tender in other Eurozone countries.

sections.section_name: Privatisation, state participation and labour movements
openai_summarised_points: • Many of Austria's largest firms were nationalized in the immediate post-World War II period to prevent Soviet takeover and to compensate for war reparations.
• During this period, the government and its conglomerate of state-owned industries played a significant role in shaping the Austrian economy.
• Starting in the early 1990s, the Austrian government began dismantling the state-owned conglomerate, leading to the privatization of many firms.
• Post-1990s reforms resulted in state-owned firms operating increasingly as private businesses, with a substantial number being wholly or partially privatized.
• The Austrian government continues to operate certain firms, including state monopolies, utilities, and service providers.
• In response to the 2008 financial crisis, Austria nationalized two banks to stabilize the financial sector.
• Since 2019, the Österreichische Industrieholding (ÖBAG) has been responsible for managing the Austrian government's investments in partially or wholly nationalized companies.
• ÖBAG has faced significant criticism following leaked messages revealing that Thomas Schmidt influenced the appointment of supervisory board members and became the sole director of ÖBAG.
• Austria maintains a well-developed industrial sector, including banking, transportation, services, and commercial facilities.
• The country has a robust labour movement, with the Austrian Trade Union Federation (ÖGB) comprising constituent unions totaling approximately 1.5 million members.
• The ÖGB represents over half of Austria's wage and salary earners.
• Since 1945, the ÖGB has adopted a moderate, consensus-oriented approach to wage policy, emphasizing cooperation with industry, agriculture, and government.
• The ÖGB has played a central role in Austria's "social partnership," engaging broadly on social and economic issues.
• The ÖGB has frequently opposed the government of Wolfgang Schüssel's programs aimed at budget consolidation, social reform, and improving the business climate.
• There are increasing indications that Austria's traditionally peaceful social climate may become more confrontational due to rising tensions between labour and government policies.
• Austrian farms are characterized by small, fragmented holdings typical of mountainous regions in Western Europe, resulting in relatively high production costs.
• Since Austria joined the European Union in 1995, the agricultural sector has undergone significant reforms under the EU's Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
• Austrian farmers supply approximately 80% of the country's domestic food requirements.
• The agricultural sector's contribution to Austria's gross domestic product (GDP) has declined from over 3% in 1950 to less than 3% in recent years.

• While some industries, such as certain iron and steel works, chemical plants, and oil corporations, are competitive on a global scale and employ thousands, most industrial and commercial enterprises in Austria are small by international standards.
• The service sector is the most significant contributor to Austria's economy, generating the majority of the country's GDP.
• Vienna has developed into a major financial and consulting hub, serving as a gateway to Eastern Europe over recent decades.
• Viennese law firms and banks are among the leading corporations engaging in business with new EU member states.
• Tourism is a crucial sector for Austria's economy, accounting for approximately 10% of the national GDP.
• In 2001, Austria was the tenth most visited country worldwide, with over 18.2 million tourists.
• Historically, Austria's tourism industry was heavily dependent on German visitors, making it vulnerable to fluctuations in the German economy.
• Recent developments have diversified tourism, with increased visitation to winter ski resorts such as Arlberg and Kitzbühel by Eastern Europeans, Russians, and Americans.
• In 2018, Austria produced the following quantities of agricultural products:
• 2.3 million tons of sugar beet, used for sugar and ethanol production;
• 2.1 million tons of maize;
• 1.3 million tons of wheat;
• 697 thousand tons of potatoes;
• 695 thousand tons of barley;
• 387 thousand tons of apples;
• 367 thousand tons of grapes;
• 278 thousand tons of triticale;
• 184 thousand tons of soybeans;
• 177 thousand tons of rye, ranking as the 12th largest producer in the world;
• 132 thousand tons of onions;
• 120 thousand tons of rapeseed;
• 111 thousand tons of pears;
• Austria also produces smaller quantities of various other agricultural products.
• The section on the "Health care services" within the "Economy of Austria" is identified as needing expansion, with a note indicating this was recognized in December 2010.
• Austrian health care spending data from 1970 to 2007 has been compared with that of other nations, suggesting a historical analysis of expenditure trends.
• Austria's health care system was initially developed concurrently with other social welfare programs, reflecting a comprehensive social policy approach.
• The development of Austria's health care system was primarily driven by the social democrats based in Vienna, indicating political influence in its foundational stages.

• Trade with other European Union (EU) countries constitutes approximately 66% of Austria's total imports and exports, making intra-EU trade the dominant component of Austria’s international trade activity.
• A significant focus of Austrian economic strategy involves expanding trade and investment in the emerging markets of Central and Eastern Europe, which are considered vital for future growth.
• Trade with Central and Eastern European countries accounts for nearly 14% of Austria’s total imports and exports, highlighting the importance of these markets to Austria’s trade portfolio.
• Austrian firms have established substantial investments in Central and Eastern Europe, reflecting a strategic move to capitalize on the region’s economic growth and market potential.

• These Austrian companies continue to relocate labor-intensive and low-tech production activities to Central and Eastern European countries, seeking cost advantages and proximity to emerging markets.

• Although the previous large-scale investment boom in the region has diminished, Austria retains significant potential to attract EU firms that are looking for convenient access to developing markets in Central and Eastern Europe.
• Since 1991, Austria has experienced significant M&A activity, with over 7,183 deals announced, totaling a known value of 261.6 billion EUR.
• In the year 2017 alone, Austria saw over 245 M&A deals with a combined value exceeding 12.9 billion EUR.
• Austrian companies have engaged in both domestic and cross-border M&A transactions, actively participating in international investment activities.

• Austrian firms have been notably active in cross-border M&A, with Germany being a particularly important partner; Austrian parent companies have acquired 854 German companies through outbound M&A deals.
• The strong bilateral relationship between Austria and Germany is exemplified by these acquisitions, indicating close economic ties.

• The financial sector in Austria is a prominent industry in M&A activity, especially in terms of transaction value, as companies seek to strengthen market positions, expand product portfolios, and enhance capabilities through mergers and acquisitions.
• When considering the number of deals, the Industrials sector leads, accounting for approximately 19.2% of all M&A transactions in Austria.
• The Industrials sector includes manufacturing, engineering, construction, transportation, and other related industries, reflecting diverse industrial interests.
• The high level of M&A activity in the Industrials sector indicates ongoing consolidation efforts, pursuit of synergies, and growth through strategic partnerships and acquisitions.
• The Austrian M&A landscape is continually evolving, influenced by market dynamics, economic conditions, and global trends, which shape strategic corporate decisions.
• Companies in Austria utilize M&A transactions as a key strategic tool for expansion, diversification, and innovation.
• The financial and Industrials sectors are expected to remain at the forefront of M&A activity in Austria, highlighting their vibrancy and potential for further growth.

• The table presents Austria’s main economic indicators from 1980 to 2021, with IMF staff estimates for 2022–2027, highlighting data such as GDP, GDP per capita, growth rates, inflation, unemployment, and government debt.
• Inflation rates under 5% are indicated in green within the table.

• In 1980, Austria’s GDP measured 84.7 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 11,227 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 80.9 billion US dollars; the GDP growth was 2.3%, inflation was 6.3%, unemployment was 1.6%, and government debt data was not available.
• The GDP steadily increased over the decades, reaching 534.0 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2021, with a GDP per capita of 59,692.1 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 477.4 billion US dollars.
• Austria experienced fluctuating GDP growth rates, with notable declines such as -6.7% in 2020, primarily due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and positive growth of 4.5% in 2021.
• Inflation remained relatively low, with rates generally below 3%, except in 2022 (5.6%) and 2023 (2.2%), with inflation under 5% highlighted in green.
• Unemployment rates varied from a low of 1.6% in 1980 to a peak of 6.5% in 2016, with a slight increase to 6.2% in 2021.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP was approximately 55.9% in 1990, gradually rising to 83.8% in 2014, then fluctuating around 83% in 2021, with projections decreasing to 70.4% by 2027.
• The nominal GDP increased from 80.9 billion US dollars in 1980 to an estimated 725.3 billion US dollars in 2027.
• The data shows consistent economic growth, with real GDP growth rates generally between 1.8% and 3.7%, except during recessionary periods such as 2009 (-3.8%) and 2020 (-6.7%).
• The table indicates a trend of increasing GDP per capita, from 10,732 US dollars (nominal) in 1980 to an estimated 68,407.3 US dollars in 2027.
• Austria’s economic indicators reflect stability and growth, with inflation rates mostly below 3% in recent years, and government debt levels gradually decreasing from peaks above 80% of GDP.
• The data underscores Austria’s transition from a relatively modest economy in 1980 to a high-income, developed economy with substantial GDP per capita and manageable inflation levels by 2027.
• In 2022, the sector with the highest number of registered companies in Austria was Services, comprising 97,733 companies.
• The second-largest sector by company count was Finance, Insurance, and Real Estate, with a total of 70,696 companies.
• Retail Trade accounted for the third-largest number of companies, totaling 59,942.
